elements.content: Three supramolecular isomers of lutetium metal–organic framework, {Lu2(H2O)4(ATA)3­·4H2O} n (Lu-ATA@RT), {Lu2(H2O)2­(C3H7NO)2­(ATA)3} n (Lu-ATA@100), and {Lu2(C3H7NO)­(ATA)3} n (Lu-ATA@150), have been obtained from the reaction of Lu­(NO3)3·6H2O with 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA) at different temperatures. The resulting structures of Lu-ATA metal–organic frameworks depend on the temperature applied during the synthesis, revealing a temperature-susceptible supramolecular isomerism. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses suggest that new compounds with formula {Lu2(S) x (ATA)3} n (S = solvent: H2O, DMF) display different three-dimensional architectures which consist of dinuclear lutetium building units. The supramolecular isomer Lu-ATA@RT, formed at room temperature, has a pcu-net topology, while its double interpenetrated analogue Lu-ATA@100 assembles at 100 °C under hydrothermal conditions. Hydrothermal synthesis at 150 °C affords formation of the dense Lu-ATA@150 cage-like framework displaying a new hexagonal-packed net topology. All Lu-ATA isomeric phases are porous and display different gas-uptake behavior toward carbon dioxide as a function of polymeric network arrangement. The luminescent properties of Lu-ATA frameworks in the solid state as well as in suspension in the presence of different solvents reveal a solvent-dependent emission.
elements.clean_text: Three supramolecular isomers of lutetium metal-organic framework, {Lu2(H2O)4(ATA)3⋅4H2O} n  (Lu-ATA@RT), {Lu2(H2O)2(C3H7NO)2(ATA)3} n  (Lu-ATA@100), and {Lu2(C3H7NO)(ATA)3} n  (Lu-ATA@150), have been obtained from the reaction of Lu(NO3)3⋅6H2O with 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA) at different temperatures. The resulting structures of Lu-ATA metal-organic frameworks depend on the temperature applied during the synthesis, revealing a temperature-susceptible supramolecular isomerism. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses suggest that new compounds with formula {Lu2(S) x (ATA)3} n  (S = solvent: H2O, DMF) display different three-dimensional architectures which consist of dinuclear lutetium building units. The supramolecular isomer Lu-ATA@RT, formed at room temperature, has a pcu-net topology, while its double interpenetrated analogue Lu-ATA@100 assembles at 100 °C under hydrothermal conditions. Hydrothermal synthesis at 150 °C affords formation of the dense Lu-ATA@150 cage-like framework displaying a new hexagonal-packed net topology. All Lu-ATA isomeric phases are porous and display different gas-uptake behavior toward carbon dioxide as a function of polymeric network arrangement. The luminescent properties of Lu-ATA frameworks in the solid state as well as in suspension in the presence of different solvents reveal a solvent-dependent emission.

elements.content: Three new porous metal−organic frameworks (Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150) with the general formula of {Lu2(S) x (ATA)3} n (where S = H2O, DMF; ATA = 2-aminoterephthalic acid) were obtained. The self-assembled systems composed of aminoterephthalate linker and lutetium ions demonstrate a case of temperature-dependent supramolecular isomerism of their crystal structures. Moreover, the difference between these crystalline isomeric forms is reflected on their gas adsorption behavior.
elements.clean_text: Three new porous metal-organic frameworks (Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150) with the general formula of {Lu2(S) x (ATA)3} n  (where S = H2O, DMF; ATA = 2-aminoterephthalic acid) were obtained. The self-assembled systems composed of aminoterephthalate linker and lutetium ions demonstrate a case of temperature-dependent supramolecular isomerism of their crystal structures. Moreover, the difference between these crystalline isomeric forms is reflected on their gas adsorption behavior.

elements.content: During the past few decades, the research field focused on porous materials has undergone a revolution with the appearance of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). These porous solids constitute a subclass of three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers formed by a combination of metal ions or metal–oxygen clusters with organic ligands. These highly crystalline microporous materials have received enormous attention due to their manifold properties, with application in many different fields, from gas adsorption and separation to catalysis, sensing and medicine.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

During the past few decades, the research field focused on porous materials has undergone a revolution with the appearance of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). These porous solids constitute a subclass of three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers formed by a combination of metal ions or metal-oxygen clusters with organic ligands. These highly crystalline microporous materials have received enormous attention due to their manifold properties, with application in many different fields, from gas adsorption and separation to catalysis, sensing and medicine.

elements.content: In general, practical applications of MOFs are directly related to their structural features. Therefore, the rational design of MOFs’ structures at the molecular as well as nano- or macrolevels is still one of the main activities in the topic. Polymorphism or supramolecular isomerism is becoming an increasingly important subject in the field of crystal engineering, as it may facilitate the design of porous polymeric materials with targeted physical properties. In this context, the unique properties of MOF polymorphs, displaying both different crystal structures and identical molecular composition, allow for the derivation of structure–property relationships solely based on structural parameters or topology of the polymeric network. There are various key factors governing the formation of MOFs’ polymorphic forms, including reaction time, temperature, concentration of precursors, pH, solvent, modulators, and so on. For example, Shi et al. report two polymorphic frameworks consisting of EuIII, 2,5-furandicarboxylic, and oxalic acids, whose formation is determined by the pH of the reaction solution. In addition, the nature of the solvent is also an important factor that influences the topology of the resulting polymeric structure. Therefore, several polymorphic forms of PbII- and CuII-based MOFs were successfully obtained using different solvents or their mixtures. Similarly, the polymorphism of 3D MOFs was found to be instigated by modulators or structure directing agents. As example, Zhu et al. isolated two polymorphic forms of augmented “Cu2-paddlewheel”-based MOFs with identical compositions but different tbo and pto topologies which are strongly correlated with the nature of the structure directing modulator used for the synthesis. Recently, Friščić et al. have highlighted the importance of in situ solid-state routes for the monitoring of MOF’s polymorphs formation.
elements.clean_text: In general, practical applications of MOFs are directly related to their structural features. Therefore, the rational design of MOFs' structures at the molecular as well as nano- or macrolevels is still one of the main activities in the topic. Polymorphism or supramolecular isomerism is becoming an increasingly important subject in the field of crystal engineering, as it may facilitate the design of porous polymeric materials with targeted physical properties. In this context, the unique properties of MOF polymorphs, displaying both different crystal structures and identical molecular composition, allow for the derivation of structure-property relationships solely based on structural parameters or topology of the polymeric network. There are various key factors governing the formation of MOFs' polymorphic forms, including reaction time, temperature, concentration of precursors, pH, solvent, modulators, and so on. For example, Shi et al. report two polymorphic frameworks consisting of EuIII, 2,5-furandicarboxylic, and oxalic acids, whose formation is determined by the pH of the reaction solution. In addition, the nature of the solvent is also an important factor that influences the topology of the resulting polymeric structure. Therefore, several polymorphic forms of PbII- and CuII-based MOFs were successfully obtained using different solvents or their mixtures. Similarly, the polymorphism of 3D MOFs was found to be instigated by modulators or structure directing agents. As example, Zhu et al. isolated two polymorphic forms of augmented "Cu2-paddlewheel"-based MOFs with identical compositions but different tbo and pto topologies which are strongly correlated with the nature of the structure directing modulator used for the synthesis. Recently, Friščić et al. have highlighted the importance of in situ solid-state routes for the monitoring of MOF's polymorphs formation.

elements.content: Although numerous individual factors or their conjunction affect the occurrence of polymorphic forms, temperature is the one of the most important variables. In particular, the use of temperature enables researchers to take advantage of entropic differences between alternative products. As illustrated by several studies, different polymorphic phases of MOFs can be obtained from a single reaction mixture held at different temperatures. Among them, the experimental and theoretical studies carried out on a series of polymorphic La-based MOFs reveal that the kinetic metastable and thermodynamic phases could be isolated as pure products over certain temperature ranges. Additionally, the temperature-dependent ground states in the energy landscape for ZnII-imidazole polymorphs were also discussed recently. The study of polymorphism is not only important in producing novel materials with target properties but may also be helpful in developing a fundamental understanding of the factors influencing crystal growth, such as reaction temperature.

elements.content:
Despite the numerous MOFs reported in the last few decades, the number of lutetium-based MOFs is very scarce.

In this work, we report the syntheses, crystal structures, adsorption, and fluorescence properties of three novel lutetium­(III) 2-aminoterephthalate MOFs, namely, Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150. These three compounds are supramolecular isomeric forms of 3D lutetium­(III) 2-aminoterephthalate framework, {Lu2(S) x (ATA)3} n (S = solvent: H2O, DMF; ATA = 2-aminoterephthalic acid), which were obtained from identical staring materials in equal metal-to-ligand ratios under different temperatures.
elements.clean_text:
Despite the numerous MOFs reported in the last few decades, the number of lutetium-based MOFs is very scarce. 

In this work, we report the syntheses, crystal structures, adsorption, and fluorescence properties of three novel lutetium(III) 2-aminoterephthalate MOFs, namely, Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150. These three compounds are supramolecular isomeric forms of 3D lutetium(III) 2-aminoterephthalate framework, {Lu2(S) x (ATA)3} n  (S = solvent: H2O, DMF; ATA = 2-aminoterephthalic acid), which were obtained from identical staring materials in equal metal-to-ligand ratios under different temperatures.

elements.content:
All starting materials were of analytical grade, obtained from Sigma-Aldrich, and used without further purification.

Syntheses

The synthetic condition for Lu-ATA@RT (room temperature supramolecular isomer) was previously optimized (see Supporting Information). A total of 0.1 g (0.26 mmol) of Lu­(NO3)3·6H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of H2O and mixed with an aqueous solution (5 mL) containing 0.14 g (0.77 mmol) of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA) and 0.04 g (1.54 mmol) of LiOH under magnetic stirring. The resulting solution was allowed to complete the reaction for 1 h at room temperature upon continuous stirring. The formed pale-yellow precipitate was separated by vacuum filtration, washed several times with distillated water, and air-dried. Yield, 0.14 g (99% based on Lu).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Characterization Methods

All starting materials were of analytical grade, obtained from Sigma-Aldrich, and used without further purification.

Syntheses

The synthetic condition for Lu-ATA@RT (room temperature supramolecular isomer) was previously optimized (see Supporting Information). A total of 0.1 g (0.26 mmol) of Lu(NO3)3⋅6H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of H2O and mixed with an aqueous solution (5 mL) containing 0.14 g (0.77 mmol) of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA) and 0.04 g (1.54 mmol) of LiOH under magnetic stirring. The resulting solution was allowed to complete the reaction for 1 h at room temperature upon continuous stirring. The formed pale-yellow precipitate was separated by vacuum filtration, washed several times with distillated water, and air-dried. Yield, 0.14 g (99% based on Lu).

elements.content: For Lu-ATA@100 (supramolecular isomer formed at 100 °C) synthesis, a mixture containing 0.1 g (0.26 mmol) of Lu­(NO3)3·6H2O, 0.05 g (0.3 mmol) of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA), 2 mL of DMF, and 8 mL of H2O was placed after dissolution in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated for 5 h at 100 °C in an oven under static conditions. The yellow precipitate was separated by vacuum filtration, washed several times with distillated water, and air-dried. Yield, 0.12 g (93% based on Lu).
elements.clean_text: For Lu-ATA@100 (supramolecular isomer formed at 100 °C) synthesis, a mixture containing 0.1 g (0.26 mmol) of Lu(NO3)3⋅6H2O, 0.05 g (0.3 mmol) of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA), 2 mL of DMF, and 8 mL of H2O was placed after dissolution in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated for 5 h at 100 °C in an oven under static conditions. The yellow precipitate was separated by vacuum filtration, washed several times with distillated water, and air-dried. Yield, 0.12 g (93% based on Lu).

elements.content: The synthesis of the Lu-ATA@150 polymorph was realized using the same reagent amounts and procedures as for Lu-ATA@100, but the reaction was performed under hydrothermal conditions at 150 °C for 5 h yielding 0.10 g of a yellow-brown powdered product (90% yield based on Lu). The solid was separated by vacuum filtration, washed several times with distillated water, and air-dried.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis of the Lu-ATA@150 polymorph was realized using the same reagent amounts and procedures as for Lu-ATA@100, but the reaction was performed under hydrothermal conditions at 150 °C for 5 h yielding 0.10 g of a yellow-brown powdered product (90% yield based on Lu). The solid was separated by vacuum filtration, washed several times with distillated water, and air-dried.

elements.content: Single crystals of Lu-ATA@RT were obtained by crystallization in a tetremethoxysilane (TMOS) gel containing (0.77 mmol) of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA) and 0.04 g (1.54 mmol) of LiOH. When the gel was formed, the aqueous solution of Lu­(NO3)3·6H2O was placed as upper layer. After 1 week, prismatic yellow crystals of Lu-ATA@RT were formed in the gel phase (Figure S1a, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal Growth

Single crystals of Lu-ATA@RT were obtained by crystallization in a tetremethoxysilane (TMOS) gel containing (0.77 mmol) of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA) and 0.04 g (1.54 mmol) of LiOH. When the gel was formed, the aqueous solution of Lu(NO3)3⋅6H2O was placed as upper layer. After 1 week, prismatic yellow crystals of Lu-ATA@RT were formed in the gel phase (Figure S1a, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to study the crystal size and morphology of the Lu-MOF polymorphs. SEM micrographs were acquired in a Philips XL20 (15–30 kV) microscope after sputtering the sample with a conductive Au layer.
elements.clean_text: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to study the crystal size and morphology of the Lu-MOF polymorphs. SEM micrographs were acquired in a Philips XL20 (15-30 kV) microscope after sputtering the sample with a conductive Au layer.

elements.content:
Mettler-Toledo TGA/SDTA851e was used for the thermal analyses in air dynamic atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the range of temperatures from 30 to 1000 °C (blank runs were performed).

CO<sub>2</sub> Adsorption

Low-pressure adsorption isotherms of CO2 (purity of 99.995%) were measured at 273 K in a device built by Bruker based on the volumetric technique. High-pressure adsorption isotherms of CO2 (purity of 99.995%) were determined using the volumetric technique with an apparatus from BEL Japan (Belsorp HP). Around 0.2 g of the samples was placed in the sample container. Before every measurement, the adsorbent was pretreated by increasing the temperature to 473 K at a rate of 10 K/min under a vacuum and maintaining the temperature for 2 h. The measurements for carbon dioxide adsorption at high pressure were carried out at 273 K for the complete series of Lu-MOF supramolecular isomers.

Thermogravimetric Analysis

Mettler-Toledo TGA/SDTA851e was used for the thermal analyses in air dynamic atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the range of temperatures from 30 to 1000 °C (blank runs were performed).

CO2 Adsorption

Low-pressure adsorption isotherms of CO2 (purity of 99.995%) were measured at 273 K in a device built by Bruker based on the volumetric technique. High-pressure adsorption isotherms of CO2 (purity of 99.995%) were determined using the volumetric technique with an apparatus from BEL Japan (Belsorp HP). Around 0.2 g of the samples was placed in the sample container. Before every measurement, the adsorbent was pretreated by increasing the temperature to 473 K at a rate of 10 K/min under a vacuum and maintaining the temperature for 2 h. The measurements for carbon dioxide adsorption at high pressure were carried out at 273 K for the complete series of Lu-MOF supramolecular isomers.

elements.content: Diffuse reflectance (BaSO4 as a white standard) and absorption UV/vis spectra were collected using a Perkin–Elmer Lambda 900 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere (“Labsphere”). Steady-state emission spectra were acquired using the photospectrometer Quanta Master QM1 of Photon Technology International (PTI) provided with a 100 W xenon lamp, a double excitation monochromator (model PTI 121 A), a sample box and an emission monochromator (model PTI 101 A), and a photon counting detector PMT (model 710).
elements.clean_text: Diffuse reflectance (BaSO4 as a white standard) and absorption UV/vis spectra were collected using a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 900 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere ("Labsphere"). Steady-state emission spectra were acquired using the photospectrometer Quanta Master QM1 of Photon Technology International (PTI) provided with a 100 W xenon lamp, a double excitation monochromator (model PTI 121 A), a sample box and an emission monochromator (model PTI 101 A), and a photon counting detector PMT (model 710).

elements.content: The single crystal X-ray diffraction data for Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150 were collected at 293 K on a an Oxford-Gemini X-ray diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromatic Cu–Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) and Mo–Kα (λ = 0.7107 Å) radiation. The CrysAlisPro program was used for cell refinement and data reduction. Images were collected at a 55 mm fixed crystal-detector distance, using the oscillation method, with 1° oscillation and variable exposure time per image. All the structures were solved by direct methods using the program SIR92 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques against F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 crystallographic software package. All non-hydrogen atoms were found from the difference Fourier maps and refined anisotropically, whereas the hydrogen atoms of the organic molecules were placed by geometrical considerations and were added to the structure factor calculations. In the case of Lu-ATA@150 structure, nitrogen atoms of amino groups are refined isotropically. Moreover, terminal amino groups of 2-aminoterephthalic ligand are disordered with an occupancy ratio near 0.5. For compounds Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150, the high residual peaks and holes are observed in the vicinity of Lu3+, which are normal for compounds containing heavy atoms. Absorption corrections were applied using the XABS2 program. The crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150 are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination

The single crystal X-ray diffraction data for Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150 were collected at 293 K on a an Oxford-Gemini X-ray diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromatic Cu-Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) and Mo-Kα (λ = 0.7107 Å) radiation. The CrysAlisPro program was used for cell refinement and data reduction. Images were collected at a 55 mm fixed crystal-detector distance, using the oscillation method, with 1° oscillation and variable exposure time per image. All the structures were solved by direct methods using the program SIR92 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques against F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 crystallographic software package. All non-hydrogen atoms were found from the difference Fourier maps and refined anisotropically, whereas the hydrogen atoms of the organic molecules were placed by geometrical considerations and were added to the structure factor calculations. In the case of Lu-ATA@150 structure, nitrogen atoms of amino groups are refined isotropically. Moreover, terminal amino groups of 2-aminoterephthalic ligand are disordered with an occupancy ratio near 0.5. For compounds Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150, the high residual peaks and holes are observed in the vicinity of Lu3+, which are normal for compounds containing heavy atoms. Absorption corrections were applied using the XABS2 program. The crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150 are summarized in .

X-ray powder diffraction patterns were collected at room temperature on a Bruker Advance D8 diffractometer using Co–Kα (λ = 1.78897 Å), equipped with a LynxEye detector. The powder diffractograms for the synthesized compound were recorded in the 5–95° range of 2θ with a step of 0.019° and a counting time of 0.4 s per step.

elements.content: Three supramolecular isomeric forms of Lu-ATA (ATA = 2-aminoterephthalic acid) coordination frameworks were obtained through the reaction of lutetium­(III) nitrate with ATA linker at different temperatures using similar intervals of precursors concentration. Although they share the same compositional characteristics, {Lu2(S) x (C8H6NO4)3} n (S = solvent: H2O or dimethylformamide, DMF), the crystal structures of these new metal–organic networks reveal temperature-dependent supramolecular isomerism. Using optimized temperature ranges, supramolecular isomers Lu-ATA@100 and Lu-ATA@150 were obtained hydrothermally as pure, highly crystalline phases (Figure S2a,b) composed of polyhedra-shaped crystals with sizes ranging from 20 to 500 μm (Figure S4). Consequently, the quality of the crystals isolated hydrothermally allows direct structure solution using single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). In contrast to above-mentioned compounds, the supramolecular isomeric phase Lu-ATA@RT, prepared at room temperature (Figures S3 and S4a,d), is composed of smaller crystals (1–3 μm). The crystal growth in gel media is very useful and widely applied technique for obtaining high quality MOFs’ single crystals. In order to carry out detailed structural analysis for Lu-ATA@RT, the crystal growth in TMOS gel media has been applied. After 1 week in the gel phase, the yellow dendritically organized crystals were formed and used for further SCXRD characterization (Figure S1a).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Three supramolecular isomeric forms of Lu-ATA (ATA = 2-aminoterephthalic acid) coordination frameworks were obtained through the reaction of lutetium(III) nitrate with ATA linker at different temperatures using similar intervals of precursors concentration. Although they share the same compositional characteristics, {Lu2(S) x (C8H6NO4)3} n  (S = solvent: H2O or dimethylformamide, DMF), the crystal structures of these new metal-organic networks reveal temperature-dependent supramolecular isomerism. Using optimized temperature ranges, supramolecular isomers Lu-ATA@100 and Lu-ATA@150 were obtained hydrothermally as pure, highly crystalline phases (Figure S2a,b) composed of polyhedra-shaped crystals with sizes ranging from 20 to 500 μm (Figure S4). Consequently, the quality of the crystals isolated hydrothermally allows direct structure solution using single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). In contrast to above-mentioned compounds, the supramolecular isomeric phase Lu-ATA@RT, prepared at room temperature (Figures S3 and S4a,d), is composed of smaller crystals (1-3 μm). The crystal growth in gel media is very useful and widely applied technique for obtaining high quality MOFs' single crystals. In order to carry out detailed structural analysis for Lu-ATA@RT, the crystal growth in TMOS gel media has been applied. After 1 week in the gel phase, the yellow dendritically organized crystals were formed and used for further SCXRD characterization (Figure S1a).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of Lu-ATA@RT reveals that this coordination polymer of formula {Lu2(H2O)4­(C8H5NO4)3­·4H2O} n crystallizes in a triclinic space group P1̅ with unit cell parameters summarized in . The asymmetric unit of Lu-ATA@RT contains one lutetium atom, one and half aminoterephthalic acid (ATA), two coordinated and two crystallization water molecules (Figure S6).
elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of Lu-ATA@RT reveals that this coordination polymer of formula {Lu2(H2O)4(C8H5NO4)3⋅4H2O} n  crystallizes in a triclinic space group P1̅ with unit cell parameters summarized in . The asymmetric unit of Lu-ATA@RT contains one lutetium atom, one and half aminoterephthalic acid (ATA), two coordinated and two crystallization water molecules (Figure S6).

elements.content: As shown in a, the lutetium center adopts a distorted bicapped trigonal prismatic geometry and is surrounded by eight oxygen atoms where six of them belong to four carboxylic groups of ATA ligands and two to coordinated water molecules. In the structure of Lu-ATA@RT, the 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA) exhibits two different tetradentate coordination modes (b,c): the mode (b) μ-(η2:η2), where two oxygen atoms of one carboxylic group chelate one lutetium ion; the mode (c) μ4-(η1:η1:η1:η1), where the aminoterephthalate dianion coordinates four lutetium centers by each available oxygen atoms proceeding from two carboxylate groups. Consequently, ATA ligands in μ-(η2:η2) and μ4-(η1:η1:η1:η1) coordination modes link lutetium ions in an alternate manner to form one-dimensional (1D) chains of Lu polyhedra extended along the b-crystallographic direction and arranging into the two-dimensional (2D) substructure of the Lu-ATA@RT framework (Figure S7d). Additionally, the ATA ligands behaving only in μ-(η2:η2) mode link lutetium ions in parallel mode and define a second 2D substructure of Lu-ATA@RT (Figure S7e). Such 2D substructures are further associated together through the angular coordination to Lu polyhedra chain resulting in a 3D framework with large rhombohedral channels running along the a- and b-crystallographic axes (a,b).

Consequently, ATA ligands in μ-(η2:η2) and μ4-(η1:η1:η1:η1) coordination modes link lutetium ions in an alternate manner to form one-dimensional (1D) chains of Lu polyhedra extended along the b-crystallographic direction and arranging into the two-dimensional (2D) substructure of the Lu-ATA@RT framework (Figure S7d). According to the void analysis performed with the PLATON program, using a probe molecule radius of 1.4 Å and a grid interval of 0.2 Å, the extended 3D structure of the Lu-ATA@RT framework possesses 150 Å3 (15.8%) of free void space. It is worth noting that the structure of the Lu-ATA@RT supramolecular isomer is formed by a dinuclear lutetium motif acting as an elementary structural building unit (SBU) and can be defined as a simple node during the topological analysis of the framework (c). Thus, according to the analysis performed by TOPOSPro, the resulting 3D arrangement corresponds to a six-connected uninodal net of pcu alpha-Po primitive cubic type with (412.63) point (Schläfli) symbol (d), where the dinuclear lutetium motif act as a node and ATA ligands as a bidentate rod.

elements.content: Compound Lu-ATA@100, with formula {Lu2(H2O)2­(C3H7NO)2­(C8H5NO4)3} n , crystallizes in a triclinic space group P1̅ with unit cell parameters summarized in . The asymmetric unit of Lu-ATA@100 is composed of one lutetium atom, one and a half aminoterephthalic acid (ATA), one coordinated water, and one coordinated DMF molecule (Figure S8). The coordination environment of the lutetium ion in Lu-ATA@100 is formed by eight oxygen atoms, where six of them (O1–O6) belong to three carboxylic groups of ATA ligands, one (O1w) to coordinated water and one (O7dmf) to coordinated DMF molecules, and adopts a distorted bicapped trigonal prismatic geometry (d). Notably, in Lu-ATA@100, the 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA) structure exhibits the same (b) μ-(η2:η2) and (c) μ4-(η1:η1:η1:η1) coordination modes (b,c) as in the Lu-ATA@RT structure. However, the ATA linker behaving in μ4-mode bridges two nearest metal centers, forming a dimeric lutetium unit as shown in a.

elements.content: Such secluded lutetium dimers are linked through μ4-bridging ATA linkers to give a 1D substructure (Figure S9). Furthermore, adjacent chains are further associated together via the linear ATA exhibiting μ-chelation, resulting in a 3D framework. As shown in b,c, the polymeric network of Lu-ATA@100 possesses open rhombohedral channels running along the b-axis. Notably, the coordinated DMF molecules of dimeric lutetium units pointing into channels restrict the aperture of the framework in the [111] direction (c). The void analysis performed by PLATON using a probe molecule radius of 1.4 Å and a grid interval of 0.2 Å reveals that the Lu-ATA@100 framework does not possess externally accessible surface volume due to interpenetration as has been proven below. According to the topological analysis, the Lu-ATA@100 framework is a uninodal six-connected net of pcu alpha-Po primitive cubic type expressed by (412.63) point (Schläfli) symbol. Moreover, the framework structure consists of two independent simple nets of pcu topology with the interpenetration belonging to the class Ia, where each net is symmetry-equivalent and related both by translation vector [100] and inversion (d). Although an increase in the densities of the obtained Lu-ATA supramolecular isomers with temperature was observed, Lu-ATA@100 showed an out-of-trend result due to network interpenetration.

elements.content: The hydrothermal synthesis of Lu-ATA@150 supramolecular isomer resulted in a dense hexagonally packed framework structure. As revealed by single crystal X-ray diffraction, the Lu-ATA@150 of formula {Lu2(C3H7NO)­(C8H5NO4)3} n crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/a with unit cell parameters given in . The asymmetric unit of Lu-ATA@150 contains four crystallographically independent lutetium atoms, six aminoterephthalic acid (ATA), and two coordinated DMF molecules (Figure S10). Three lutetium ions (Lu1, Lu3, and Lu4) adopt a distorted monocapped trigonal prismatic coordination geometry (a–c,d) by participation of seven oxygen atoms: (a), (c) all of them from carboxylate groups of ATA ligands (Lu1 and Lu3 centers); (d) six from carboxylate groups of ATA ligands and one (O26dmf) from coordinated DMF molecule (Lu4 center).

As revealed by single crystal X-ray diffraction, the Lu-ATA@150 of formula {Lu2(C3H7NO)(C8H5NO4)3} n  crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/a with unit cell parameters given in . The asymmetric unit of Lu-ATA@150 contains four crystallographically independent lutetium atoms, six aminoterephthalic acid (ATA), and two coordinated DMF molecules (Figure S10). Three lutetium ions (Lu1, Lu3, and Lu4) adopt a distorted monocapped trigonal prismatic coordination geometry (a-c,d) by participation of seven oxygen atoms: (a), (c) all of them from carboxylate groups of ATA ligands (Lu1 and Lu3 centers); (d) six from carboxylate groups of ATA ligands and one (O26dmf) from coordinated DMF molecule (Lu4 center).

The coordination environment of central lutetium atom Lu2 consists of a distorted bicapped trigonal prismatic geometry comprising eight oxygen atoms: seven of them are originated from carboxylate groups of ATA ligands and one (O25dmf) from a coordinated DMF molecule (b). In the structure of the Lu-ATA@150 supramolecular isomer, the 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA) exhibits three different tetradentate coordination modes (e–g): the mode (e) μ4-(η1:η1:η1:η1), where the aminoterephthalate linker coordinates four lutetium centers by each available oxygen atoms from two carboxyl groups; the mode (f) μ4-(η1:η1:η1:η2), where three oxygen atoms of two carboxyl groups coordinate to three lutetium centers and chelate fourth one; the mode (g) μ4-(η1:η2:η1:η2), where each of carboxyl groups coordinates to one lutetium center and chelates the second one.

In the structure of the Lu-ATA@150 supramolecular isomer, the 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA) exhibits three different tetradentate coordination modes (e-g): the mode (e) μ4-(η1:η1:η1:η1), where the aminoterephthalate linker coordinates four lutetium centers by each available oxygen atoms from two carboxyl groups; the mode (f) μ4-(η1:η1:η1:η2), where three oxygen atoms of two carboxyl groups coordinate to three lutetium centers and chelate fourth one; the mode (g) μ4-(η1:η2:η1:η2), where each of carboxyl groups coordinates to one lutetium center and chelates the second one.

elements.content: As seen in a, the neighboring lutetium atoms are connected together through the carboxylate groups of ATA ligands () in (e–g) coordination fashions to form an infinite chain of lutetium polyhedra running along the crystallographic b-axis. Notably, the polymeric 1D chain consists of two types of dinuclear motifs (b,c): (b) edge-sharing and (c) corner-sharing units. Furthermore, the 1D skeleton of lutetium centers is extended by ATA linkers resulting in a hexagonally packed 3D supramolecular architecture. As shown in d, the polymeric network of Lu-ATA@150 is a cage-like structure with triangular windows which are partially obstructed by coordinated DMF molecules of 1D lutetium skeleton. The solvent-accessible volume of Lu-ATA@150 calculated by PLATON is 374.6 Å3 (a probe molecule radius of 1.4 Å and a grid interval of 0.2 Å were used) and corresponds to 6.1% of the unit cell volume. Moreover, the polymeric network of Lu-ATA@150 is four-nodal 3,4,4,9-connected net of new topological type with a (4.52)2(44.5.6)­(44.52)­(48.512.616)2 point (Schläfli) symbol (e). In the simplification procedure, the dinuclear lutetium motifs act as nine-connected nodes, while the ATA ligands as bidentate rods, three-connected and four connected nodes (Figure S11). Interestingly, because of the cage-like structure of Lu-ATA@150, the empty space of the network can be represented by tilling with [4 9 11 6] tile transitivity (f).

elements.content: Thermal stability in air atmosphere of the three Lu-ATA supramolecular isomers was investigated, and the thermal decomposition profiles are shown in Figure S12. The degradation of Lu-ATA@RT proceeds in two stages, as depicted in Figure S12a. The first mass loss between 30 and 120 °C with a total mass loss of 15.5% (calculated 14.8%) corresponds to the simultaneous release of four water molecules trapped in the pores and four coordinated to lutetium atoms, which is accompanied by an endothermic peak in the SDTA curve. Up to 300 °C, the resulting anhydrous compound remains stable until the second stage, which takes place in the range 320–540 °C (continuous process) with the total mass loss of ca. 44.4% and corresponds to the progressive decomposition of the organic part of the framework, associated with exothermic peaks in the SDTA graph. According to the mass of the remaining solid, the residual product of decomposition is Lu2O3

elements.content: In turn, the thermal decomposition profile of Lu-ATA@100 shows a different behavior and is composed of two well-separated steps. As shown in Figure S12b, the first mass loss step occurs at a higher temperature in the range 170–230 °C with the mass loss of 16.3% and consists of two contributions which correspond to evacuation of two coordinated water and two DMF molecules (calculated 16.5%). These processes are conformed by an endothermic peak in SDTA plot. The anhydrous framework of Lu-ATA@100 remains stable up to 340 °C. The second decomposition stage takes place in the range 350–550 °C with the mass loss of ca. 61.2% and is attributed to oxidative degradation of the organic part of the polymeric frame, associated with exothermic peaks in the SDTA curve.

elements.content: Similarly, the degradation process for Lu-ATA@150 supramolecular isomer proceeds in two stages (Figure S12c). The first mass loss between 140 and 230 °C with a mass loss of 7.6% (calculated 7.3%) corresponds to the evacuation of two DMF molecules coordinated to lutetium atoms, which is accompanied by an endothermic peak in the SDTA curve. In air atmosphere, the anhydrous Lu-ATA@150 is stable in the 240–320 °C temperature plateau, followed by a second degradation step, which takes place in the range 330–700 °C. The total mass loss of ca. 57.3% corresponds to the decomposition of organic ligands and collapse of the structure (exothermic process).

elements.content: In order to explore any structural transformation that can take place upon activation of the Lu-ATA isomers and be related to the solvent removal, additional powder X-ray diffraction studies have been performed. As shown in Figures S13 and S14, PXRD patterns of Lu-ATA@RT and Lu-ATA@100 treated in vacuo at 200 °C show a loss of crystallinity without any notable structural transformations. In contrast, Lu-ATA@150 exhibits irreversible structural change upon activation at 200 °C in vacuo, as illustrated in Figure S15. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of Lu-ATA@150 desolvated form has been indexed in the triclinic crystal system with the following unit cell dimensions: a = 10.56(2) Å, b = 10.33(2) Å, c = 7.48(1) Å, α = 95.6(1)°, β = 109.2(1)°, γ = 113.3(2)°, V = 683(2) Å3. The results reveal that the unit cell contracts after desolvation process lowering the crystal symmetry to P1̅.

elements.content: The porosity of the three supramolecular isomers could not be studied with nitrogen physisorption due to the very narrow porosity that these materials exhibit. That fact, in combination with the big crystal size, led to diffusional problems and made carbon dioxide adsorption a suitable choice for their textural characterization as it has been proposed several times in the literature. The adsorption of carbon dioxide on the series of materials was analyzed at 273 K at low and high pressure.

elements.content: At carbon dioxide pressure up to 100 kPa, Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150 adsorb a similar amount, around 0.7, 0.65, and 0.59 mmol/g, respectively. It is important to notice that the removal of coordinated DMF molecules, which restricts the accessibility to a vacant pore space in Lu-ATA@100 and Lu-ATA@150 frameworks, is essential to obtain adsorption of carbon dioxide. When the pretreatment was carried out at 323 K, the materials did not show any uptake, in contrast the porosity was accessible if temperatures higher than 373 K were applied to pretreat the samples. At higher pressures the same trend is confirmed, Lu-ATA@150 being the material with lower adsorption capacity with a maximum value of 1.56 mmol/g at 2636 kPa. Lu-ATA@100 adsorbs a higher amount reaching 2.2 mmol/g at 2299 kPa. The material with the highest adsorption capacity for carbon dioxide of the supramolecular isomers series is Lu-ATA@150, adsorbing a maximum of 2.7 mmol/g at 2656 kPa. The adsorption trend of the three supramolecular isomers is in agreement with the obtained pore volumes from the crystallographic information, the three of them exhibiting a very narrow porosity.

elements.content: The optical properties of the Lu-ATA MOFs series were analyzed by light absorption and fluorescence spectroscopy. The three isomeric structures show fluorescence emission in the solid state as well as in suspension of acetonitrile and toluene (). Lu­(III) has full f orbitals and thus the typical lanthanide metal luminescence cannot occur. The band at longest wavelength in the free linker, assigned to a highest occupied molecular orbital to lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (HOMO–LUMO) transition with a n → π* nature, appears in the MOFs’ spectra without important shifts. This seems to indicate that the contribution of the metal orbitals to the frontier orbitals might be negligible and that this transition remains linker based in the MOFs. Nevertheless, computational studies are needed to gain insights into the location of HOMO and LUMO in each Lu-ATA system and thus to confirm if the bands around 370–380 nm arise from linker based or metal-to-linker charge-transfer (MLCT) transitions.

elements.content: It is known that increasing the polarity of the solvent leads to blue shifts in nπ* transitions. In the ground state, the dipoles of the solvent are oriented with their positive endings toward the n orbital bearing the lone pair of electrons. Upon excitation the n orbital loses electron density (which is injected into the π*) but the solvent dipoles do not switch in this time scale, and thus a repulsive effect between the solvent molecules and the electron-poor nitrogen destabilizes the excited state.
elements.clean_text: It is known that increasing the polarity of the solvent leads to blue shifts in nπ* transitions. In the ground state, the dipoles of the solvent are oriented with their positive endings toward the n orbital bearing the lone pair of electrons. Upon excitation the n orbital loses electron density (which is injected into the π*) but the solvent dipoles do not switch in this time scale, and thus a repulsive effect between the solvent molecules and the electron-poor nitrogen destabilizes the excited state.

elements.content: Thus, a possible explanation for the different blue shifts of each Lu-ATA MOF suspended in acetonitrile compared to the corresponding spectra in powder and in toluene could be that the polar solvent molecules interact with a different strength with each supramolecular isomer, thus leading to different degrees of destabilization of their excited state. That is, solvatochromism might be different for each Lu-ATA structure. Nevertheless, MOFs can undergo several mechanisms that lead to optical changes, and further studies would be required to unequivocally explain this trend.

elements.content: Three supramolecular isomeric forms of lutetium-based MOF, Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150, built by a 2-aminoterephthalic linker were synthesized starting from the same precursors. The structure of the final isomeric form of the Lu-ATA framework as well as its crystal packing is influenced by the temperature applied during the synthesis. Thus, the room temperature approach leads to formation of Lu-ATA@RT framework having pcu topology, while the synthesis at 100 °C results in Lu-ATA@100 forming an interpenetrated (class Ia) analogue of the pcu-net. A dense cage-like structure with a new topology is formed at 150 °C under hydrothermal conditions (Lu-ATA@150). Notably, the structural differences between three supramolecular isomers of Lu-ATA MOF expressed by the general formula of {Lu2(S) x (ATA)3} n are reflected in their absorption behavior toward CO2. High-pressure CO2 absorption results reveal that the three Lu-ATA supramolecular isomers possess narrow porosity, the maximum capacity follows the trend Lu-ATA@RT > Lu-ATA@100 > Lu-ATA@150, in agreement with the calculated pore volumes extracted from the crystallographic information. Lu-ATA series suspended in acetonitrile exhibited a blue shift of different magnitude in their absorption and emission bands compared to the spectra in toluene or in powder, which might be an indication of different solvation efficiency in the diverse structures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three supramolecular isomeric forms of lutetium-based MOF, Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150, built by a 2-aminoterephthalic linker were synthesized starting from the same precursors. The structure of the final isomeric form of the Lu-ATA framework as well as its crystal packing is influenced by the temperature applied during the synthesis. Thus, the room temperature approach leads to formation of Lu-ATA@RT framework having pcu topology, while the synthesis at 100 °C results in Lu-ATA@100 forming an interpenetrated (class Ia) analogue of the pcu-net. A dense cage-like structure with a new topology is formed at 150 °C under hydrothermal conditions (Lu-ATA@150). Notably, the structural differences between three supramolecular isomers of Lu-ATA MOF expressed by the general formula of {Lu2(S) x (ATA)3} n  are reflected in their absorption behavior toward CO2. High-pressure CO2 absorption results reveal that the three Lu-ATA supramolecular isomers possess narrow porosity, the maximum capacity follows the trend Lu-ATA@RT > Lu-ATA@100 > Lu-ATA@150, in agreement with the calculated pore volumes extracted from the crystallographic information. Lu-ATA series suspended in acetonitrile exhibited a blue shift of different magnitude in their absorption and emission bands compared to the spectra in toluene or in powder, which might be an indication of different solvation efficiency in the diverse structures.

cln_elements.content:
All starting materials were of analytical grade, obtained from Sigma-Aldrich, and used without further purification.

Syntheses

The synthetic condition for Lu-ATA@RT (room temperature supramolecular isomer) was previously optimized (see Supporting Information). A total of 0.1 g (0.26 mmol) of Lu­(NO3)3·6H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of H2O and mixed with an aqueous solution (5 mL) containing 0.14 g (0.77 mmol) of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA) and 0.04 g (1.54 mmol) of LiOH under magnetic stirring. The resulting solution was allowed to complete the reaction for 1 h at room temperature upon continuous stirring. The formed pale-yellow precipitate was separated by vacuum filtration, washed several times with distillated water, and air-dried. Yield, 0.14 g (99% based on Lu).

For Lu-ATA@100 (supramolecular isomer formed at 100 °C) synthesis, a mixture containing 0.1 g (0.26 mmol) of Lu­(NO3)3·6H2O, 0.05 g (0.3 mmol) of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA), 2 mL of DMF, and 8 mL of H2O was placed after dissolution in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated for 5 h at 100 °C in an oven under static conditions. The yellow precipitate was separated by vacuum filtration, washed several times with distillated water, and air-dried. Yield, 0.12 g (93% based on Lu).

The synthesis of the Lu-ATA@150 polymorph was realized using the same reagent amounts and procedures as for Lu-ATA@100, but the reaction was performed under hydrothermal conditions at 150 °C for 5 h yielding 0.10 g of a yellow-brown powdered product (90% yield based on Lu). The solid was separated by vacuum filtration, washed several times with distillated water, and air-dried.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Characterization Methods

All starting materials were of analytical grade, obtained from Sigma-Aldrich, and used without further purification.

Syntheses

The synthetic condition for Lu-ATA@RT (room temperature supramolecular isomer) was previously optimized (see Supporting Information). A total of 0.1 g (0.26 mmol) of Lu(NO3)3⋅6H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of H2O and mixed with an aqueous solution (5 mL) containing 0.14 g (0.77 mmol) of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA) and 0.04 g (1.54 mmol) of LiOH under magnetic stirring. The resulting solution was allowed to complete the reaction for 1 h at room temperature upon continuous stirring. The formed pale-yellow precipitate was separated by vacuum filtration, washed several times with distillated water, and air-dried. Yield, 0.14 g (99% based on Lu).

For Lu-ATA@100 (supramolecular isomer formed at 100 °C) synthesis, a mixture containing 0.1 g (0.26 mmol) of Lu(NO3)3⋅6H2O, 0.05 g (0.3 mmol) of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (ATA), 2 mL of DMF, and 8 mL of H2O was placed after dissolution in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated for 5 h at 100 °C in an oven under static conditions. The yellow precipitate was separated by vacuum filtration, washed several times with distillated water, and air-dried. Yield, 0.12 g (93% based on Lu).

The synthesis of the Lu-ATA@150 polymorph was realized using the same reagent amounts and procedures as for Lu-ATA@100, but the reaction was performed under hydrothermal conditions at 150 °C for 5 h yielding 0.10 g of a yellow-brown powdered product (90% yield based on Lu). The solid was separated by vacuum filtration, washed several times with distillated water, and air-dried.

cln_elements.content:
Hydrogen atoms of benzene ring were omitted for clarity. Lutetium atoms are depicted as violet spheres.

According to the void analysis performed with the PLATON program, using a probe molecule radius of 1.4 Å and a grid interval of 0.2 Å, the extended 3D structure of the Lu-ATA@RT framework possesses 150 Å3 (15.8%) of free void space. It is worth noting that the structure of the Lu-ATA@RT supramolecular isomer is formed by a dinuclear lutetium motif acting as an elementary structural building unit (SBU) and can be defined as a simple node during the topological analysis of the framework (c). Thus, according to the analysis performed by TOPOSPro, the resulting 3D arrangement corresponds to a six-connected uninodal net of pcu alpha-Po primitive cubic type with (412.63) point (Schläfli) symbol (d), where the dinuclear lutetium motif act as a node and ATA ligands as a bidentate rod.

Thermal stability in air atmosphere of the three Lu-ATA supramolecular isomers was investigated, and the thermal decomposition profiles are shown in Figure S12. The degradation of Lu-ATA@RT proceeds in two stages, as depicted in Figure S12a. The first mass loss between 30 and 120 °C with a total mass loss of 15.5% (calculated 14.8%) corresponds to the simultaneous release of four water molecules trapped in the pores and four coordinated to lutetium atoms, which is accompanied by an endothermic peak in the SDTA curve. Up to 300 °C, the resulting anhydrous compound remains stable until the second stage, which takes place in the range 320–540 °C (continuous process) with the total mass loss of ca. 44.4% and corresponds to the progressive decomposition of the organic part of the framework, associated with exothermic peaks in the SDTA graph. According to the mass of the remaining solid, the residual product of decomposition is Lu2O3

In turn, the thermal decomposition profile of Lu-ATA@100 shows a different behavior and is composed of two well-separated steps. As shown in Figure S12b, the first mass loss step occurs at a higher temperature in the range 170–230 °C with the mass loss of 16.3% and consists of two contributions which correspond to evacuation of two coordinated water and two DMF molecules (calculated 16.5%). These processes are conformed by an endothermic peak in SDTA plot. The anhydrous framework of Lu-ATA@100 remains stable up to 340 °C. The second decomposition stage takes place in the range 350–550 °C with the mass loss of ca. 61.2% and is attributed to oxidative degradation of the organic part of the polymeric frame, associated with exothermic peaks in the SDTA curve.

Similarly, the degradation process for Lu-ATA@150 supramolecular isomer proceeds in two stages (Figure S12c). The first mass loss between 140 and 230 °C with a mass loss of 7.6% (calculated 7.3%) corresponds to the evacuation of two DMF molecules coordinated to lutetium atoms, which is accompanied by an endothermic peak in the SDTA curve. In air atmosphere, the anhydrous Lu-ATA@150 is stable in the 240–320 °C temperature plateau, followed by a second degradation step, which takes place in the range 330–700 °C. The total mass loss of ca. 57.3% corresponds to the decomposition of organic ligands and collapse of the structure (exothermic process).

At carbon dioxide pressure up to 100 kPa, Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150 adsorb a similar amount, around 0.7, 0.65, and 0.59 mmol/g, respectively. It is important to notice that the removal of coordinated DMF molecules, which restricts the accessibility to a vacant pore space in Lu-ATA@100 and Lu-ATA@150 frameworks, is essential to obtain adsorption of carbon dioxide. When the pretreatment was carried out at 323 K, the materials did not show any uptake, in contrast the porosity was accessible if temperatures higher than 373 K were applied to pretreat the samples. At higher pressures the same trend is confirmed, Lu-ATA@150 being the material with lower adsorption capacity with a maximum value of 1.56 mmol/g at 2636 kPa. Lu-ATA@100 adsorbs a higher amount reaching 2.2 mmol/g at 2299 kPa. The material with the highest adsorption capacity for carbon dioxide of the supramolecular isomers series is Lu-ATA@150, adsorbing a maximum of 2.7 mmol/g at 2656 kPa. The adsorption trend of the three supramolecular isomers is in agreement with the obtained pore volumes from the crystallographic information, the three of them exhibiting a very narrow porosity.
cln_elements.clean_text:
a Hydrogen atoms of benzene ring were omitted for clarity. Lutetium atoms are depicted as violet spheres.  

According to the void analysis performed with the PLATON program, using a probe molecule radius of 1.4 Å and a grid interval of 0.2 Å, the extended 3D structure of the Lu-ATA@RT framework possesses 150 Å3 (15.8%) of free void space. It is worth noting that the structure of the Lu-ATA@RT supramolecular isomer is formed by a dinuclear lutetium motif acting as an elementary structural building unit (SBU) and can be defined as a simple node during the topological analysis of the framework (c). Thus, according to the analysis performed by TOPOSPro, the resulting 3D arrangement corresponds to a six-connected uninodal net of pcu alpha-Po primitive cubic type with (412.63) point (Schläfli) symbol (d), where the dinuclear lutetium motif act as a node and ATA ligands as a bidentate rod.

Thermal stability in air atmosphere of the three Lu-ATA supramolecular isomers was investigated, and the thermal decomposition profiles are shown in Figure S12. The degradation of Lu-ATA@RT proceeds in two stages, as depicted in Figure S12a. The first mass loss between 30 and 120 °C with a total mass loss of 15.5% (calculated 14.8%) corresponds to the simultaneous release of four water molecules trapped in the pores and four coordinated to lutetium atoms, which is accompanied by an endothermic peak in the SDTA curve. Up to 300 °C, the resulting anhydrous compound remains stable until the second stage, which takes place in the range 320-540 °C (continuous process) with the total mass loss of ca. 44.4% and corresponds to the progressive decomposition of the organic part of the framework, associated with exothermic peaks in the SDTA graph. According to the mass of the remaining solid, the residual product of decomposition is Lu2O3 

In turn, the thermal decomposition profile of Lu-ATA@100 shows a different behavior and is composed of two well-separated steps. As shown in Figure S12b, the first mass loss step occurs at a higher temperature in the range 170-230 °C with the mass loss of 16.3% and consists of two contributions which correspond to evacuation of two coordinated water and two DMF molecules (calculated 16.5%). These processes are conformed by an endothermic peak in SDTA plot. The anhydrous framework of Lu-ATA@100 remains stable up to 340 °C. The second decomposition stage takes place in the range 350-550 °C with the mass loss of ca. 61.2% and is attributed to oxidative degradation of the organic part of the polymeric frame, associated with exothermic peaks in the SDTA curve.

Similarly, the degradation process for Lu-ATA@150 supramolecular isomer proceeds in two stages (Figure S12c). The first mass loss between 140 and 230 °C with a mass loss of 7.6% (calculated 7.3%) corresponds to the evacuation of two DMF molecules coordinated to lutetium atoms, which is accompanied by an endothermic peak in the SDTA curve. In air atmosphere, the anhydrous Lu-ATA@150 is stable in the 240-320 °C temperature plateau, followed by a second degradation step, which takes place in the range 330-700 °C. The total mass loss of ca. 57.3% corresponds to the decomposition of organic ligands and collapse of the structure (exothermic process).

At carbon dioxide pressure up to 100 kPa, Lu-ATA@RT, Lu-ATA@100, and Lu-ATA@150 adsorb a similar amount, around 0.7, 0.65, and 0.59 mmol/g, respectively. It is important to notice that the removal of coordinated DMF molecules, which restricts the accessibility to a vacant pore space in Lu-ATA@100 and Lu-ATA@150 frameworks, is essential to obtain adsorption of carbon dioxide. When the pretreatment was carried out at 323 K, the materials did not show any uptake, in contrast the porosity was accessible if temperatures higher than 373 K were applied to pretreat the samples. At higher pressures the same trend is confirmed, Lu-ATA@150  being the material with lower adsorption capacity with a maximum value of 1.56 mmol/g at 2636 kPa. Lu-ATA@100 adsorbs a higher amount reaching 2.2 mmol/g at 2299 kPa. The material with the highest adsorption capacity for carbon dioxide of the supramolecular isomers series is Lu-ATA@150, adsorbing a maximum of 2.7 mmol/g at 2656 kPa. The adsorption trend of the three supramolecular isomers is in agreement with the obtained pore volumes from the crystallographic information, the three of them exhibiting a very narrow porosity.
